lead_paragraph: A British newspaper identified its source as Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who has worked at the National Security Agency as a contractor.

headline.seo: Edward Snowden, Ex-C.I.A. Worker, Says He Disclosed U.S. Surveillance
headline.main: Ex-Worker at C.I.A. Says He Leaked Data on Surveillance
headline.print_headline: EX-C.I.A. WORKER SAYS HE DISCLOSED U.S. SURVEILLANCE

abstract: "Edward Joseph Snowden, 29-year-old Central Intelligence Agency computer technician, goes public as source behind the daily drumbeat of disclosures about nation's surveillance programs;" says he took the extraordinary step to inform the American public so that it can decide whether such policies are wrong.
snippet: A British newspaper identified its source as Edward Snowden, a former C.I.A. employee who has worked at the National Security Agency as a contractor.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Keith Bradsher from Hong Kong, Nicole Perlroth from San Francisco, and Emmarie Huetteman and David E. Sanger from Washington.
byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

lead_paragraph: Leaders in Congress and the intelligence committees strongly support the National Security Agency programs, and use national security arguments to trump privacy concerns.

headline.main: Debate on Secret Data Looks Unlikely, Partly Because of Secrecy
headline.print_headline: Debate on Secret Data Looks Unlikely, Partly Due to Secrecy

abstract: "Legal and political obstacles to public debate about civil liberties regarding National Security Agency's surveillance of citizens are formidable;" Congressional leaders from both parties have expressed support for newly disclosed initiatives, saying national security trumps privacy concerns, and legislation governing such surveillance was renewed for five years at the end of 2012; so far, there is no groundswell of public anger to shift Congressional views.
snippet: Leaders in Congress and the intelligence committees strongly support the National Security Agency programs, and use national security arguments to trump privacy concerns.

byline.contributor: David E. Sanger contributed reporting from Washington, Somini Sengupta from San Francisco, and Megan Thee-Brenan from New York.
byline.original: By SCOTT SHANE and JONATHAN WEISMAN

lead_paragraph: Edward J. Snowden’s positive view of Hong Kong’s protection of individual liberties does not match our reality.

headline.seo: Hong Kong, a Strange Place to Seek Freedom
headline.main: Hong Kong, a Strange Place to Seek Freedom
headline.print_headline: Hong Kong, a Strange Place to Seek Freedom

snippet: Edward J. Snowden’s positive view of Hong Kong’s protection of individual liberties does not match our reality.

keywords.value: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: The suit, which also seeks to have the records purged, could set up an eventual Supreme Court test.

headline.seo: A.C.L.U. Files Suit Over Phone Surveillance Program
headline.main: A.C.L.U. Files Lawsuit Seeking to Stop the Collection of Domestic Phone Logs
headline.print_headline: A.C.L.U. Files Lawsuit Seeking to Stop the Collection of Domestic Phone Logs

abstract: American Civil Liberties Union sues Obama administration over its collection of logs of domestic phone calls; contends that once-secret program, whose existence was exposed by former National Security Agency contractor Edward J Snowden, is illegal; ask judge to halt program and order records purged.
snippet: The suit, which also seeks to have the records purged, could set up an eventual Supreme Court test.

headline.main: The Early Word: Escalating

abstract: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.
snippet: Political news from today’s Times and around the Web, plus a look at the latest happenings in Washington.

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)

lead_paragraph: President Rafael Correa risks preferential status for several key Ecuadorean exports if he angers Washington.

headline.main: Ecuador Risks Trade Problems With U.S. if It Grants Asylum to Snowden
headline.print_headline: Ecuador Risks Trade Problems With U.S. if It Grants Asylum to Snowden

abstract: Pres Rafael Correa of Ecuador, who is weighing asylum request from fugitive intelligence contractor Edward J Snowden, risks both ire of United States and preferential status for several key Ecuadorean exports if he grants request; decision may rest ultimately on combative personality of Correa and his desire to take over leadership of Latin American left.
snippet: President Rafael Correa risks preferential status for several key Ecuadorean exports if he angers Washington.

byline.contributor: William Neuman reported from Quito, Ecuador, and Mark Landler from Washington. Maggy Ayala contributed reporting from Quito.
byline.original: By WILLIAM NEUMAN and MARK LANDLER

lead_paragraph: The tiny South American nation signaled it may take its time with Edward J. Snowden’s application, raising the possibility that he could spend weeks in legal limbo.

headline.main: Ecuador Hints at Slow Process on Snowden Asylum
headline.print_headline: Ecuador Hints Snowden May Need to Wait Awhile

abstract: Ecuador signals that it may deliberate slowly on asylum application from Edward J Snowden, raising possibility that he could spend weeks in legal limbo as he plots next steps inside Moscow airport transit area.
snippet: The tiny South American nation signaled it may take its time with Edward J. Snowden’s application, raising the possibility that he could spend weeks in legal limbo.

byline.contributor: David M. Herszenhorn reported from Moscow, and Rick Gladstone from New York. Reporting was contributed by Ellen Barry and Andrew Roth from Moscow; Peter Baker from Washington; and William Neuman from Quito, Ecuador.
byline.original: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and RICK GLADSTONE

lead_paragraph: The president commented on the United States' request to extradite the former National Security Agency computer technician at a news conference in Dakar, Senegal, on Thursday.

headline.main: Obama on Edward J. Snowden

snippet: The president commented on the United States' request to extradite the former National Security Agency computer technician at a news conference in Dakar, Senegal, on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: President Obama called Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive accused of leaking secrets, a “29-year-old hacker” whose extradition should be routine.

headline.main: Obama Seeks to Play Down Snowden’s Import
headline.print_headline: Obama Seeks to Play Down Significance of Fugitive Leaker

abstract: Pres Obama seeks to minimize significance of fugitive Edward J Snowden, calling him '29-year-old hacker;' suggests American frustration with China and Russia for apparently helping hacker evade extradition is not worth damaging relations with those countries; remarks come as new confusion swirls over Snowden's ultimate destination.
snippet: President Obama called Edward J. Snowden, the fugitive accused of leaking secrets, a “29-year-old hacker” whose extradition should be routine.

byline.contributor: Ellen Barry reported from Moscow; Michael D. Shear from Dakar, Senegal; and William Neuman from Quevedo, Ecuador. Rick Gladstone contributed reporting from New York, Andrew Roth from Moscow, and Chris Buckley from Hong Kong.
byline.original: By ELLEN BARRY, MICHAEL D. SHEAR and WILLIAM NEUMAN

lead_paragraph: Wherever he goes, whatever else is on his agenda, President Obama has made a point of reassuring Americans that he is not spying on them.

headline.main: After Leaks, Obama Leads Damage Control Effort
headline.print_headline: After Leaks, Obama Leads Wide Effort On Damage Control

abstract: White House Memo; Pres Obama has made a point of reassuring Americans that he is not spying on them, no matter what else is on his agenda; his statements are a part of a carefully orchestrated White House damage-control effort in response to revelations about surveillance programs that have unnerved many Americans and exposed him to criticism.
snippet: Wherever he goes, whatever else is on his agenda, President Obama has made a point of reassuring Americans that he is not spying on them.

keywords.value: Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board
keywords.name: organizations

lead_paragraph: The former security contractor denounced President Obama, accusing him of blocking his efforts to seek asylum.

headline.main: Snowden Is Said to Claim U.S. Is Blocking Asylum Bids
headline.print_headline: Leaker Is Said To Claim U.S. Is Blocking Asylum Bids

abstract: WikiLeaks issues statement attributed to Edward J Snowden that accuses Pres Obama of seeking to deceive the world and intimidate him by revoking his passport and opposing his asylum requests because of his disclosures about vast global surveillance efforts of American intelligence agencies; also claims in statement that United States is blocking his asylum bids in other countries.
snippet: The former security contractor denounced President Obama, accusing him of blocking his efforts to seek asylum.

byline.contributor: Rick Gladstone reported from New York, and William Neuman from Quito, Ecuador.
byline.original: By RICK GLADSTONE and WILLIAM NEUMAN

lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin said that the United States had frightened other countries that might have accepted Edward J. Snowden.

headline.main: Putin Says U.S. Trapped Snowden in Russia
headline.print_headline: Putin Says U.S. Trapped Snowden In Russia

abstract: Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin tells audience of students, doing research in Gulf of Finland, that United States effectively trapped Edward J Snowden on Russian territory by frightening countries that otherwise might have accepted him; Snowden has said that he will formally request asylum in Russia.
snippet: President Vladimir V. Putin said that the United States had frightened other countries that might have accepted Edward J. Snowden.

lead_paragraph: A secret court has sided with Yahoo and ordered the Obama administration to publish a court decision justifying Prism, the data collection program revealed by Edward J. Snowden.

headline.main: Court Orders Declassification of Decision on Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Court Orders Declassification of Decision On Surveillance

abstract: Secret court overseeing government surveillance programs sides with Yahoo and orders Obama administration to declassify and publish a 2008 court decision justifying Prism, data collection program revealed by former security contractor Edward J Sowden.
snippet: A secret court has sided with Yahoo and ordered the Obama administration to publish a court decision justifying Prism, the data collection program revealed by Edward J. Snowden.

lead_paragraph: Lawmakers from both parties called for the collection of the private data of millions of Americans to be scaled back.

headline.main: Bipartisan Backlash Grows Against Domestic Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Bipartisan Backlash Grows Against Domestic Surveillance

abstract: Obama administration faces growing Congressional backlash against National Security Agency's domestic surveillance operations, as lawmakers from both parties call for vast collection of private data on millions of Americans to be scaled back.
snippet: Lawmakers from both parties called for the collection of the private data of millions of Americans to be scaled back.

headline.main: Yes We Can to Yes We Scan

abstract: Three versions of Shepard Fairey’s “HOPE” poster show growing disaffection with government.
snippet: Three versions of Shepard Fairey’s “HOPE” poster show growing disaffection with government.

lead_paragraph: If President Obama canceled the meeting in Moscow, it would be seen as a direct slap at President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline.main: Obama May Cancel Moscow Trip as Tensions Build Over Leaker
headline.print_headline: Obama May Cancel Moscow Trip as Tensions Build Over Leaker

abstract: Pres Obama may cancel scheduled trip to Moscow to meet with Pres Vladimir V Putin in September, move that would be seen as direct slap at Putin; consideration comes during escalation of standoff over Edward J Snowden, who is seeking asylum there, and reflects broader concern that countries are far apart on issues like Syria, Iran and arms control.
snippet: If President Obama canceled the meeting in Moscow, it would be seen as a direct slap at President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

byline.contributor: Thom Shanker contributed reporting from Washington, David E. Sanger from Aspen, Colo., and Gerry Mullany from Hong Kong.

lead_paragraph: The 217-205 vote was far closer than expected and displayed the shifting allegiances and fierce lobbying on both sides of the issue.

headline.main: House Defeats Effort to Rein In N.S.A. Data Gathering
headline.print_headline: House’s Attempt  to Rein In N.S.A. Narrowly Fails

abstract: "Deeply divided House defeats legislation that would have blocked National Security Agency from collecting vast amounts of phone records;" vote hands Obama administration a hard-fought victory over NSA's surveillance activities since Edward J Snowden's security breaches; 217-205 vote is far closer than expected and displays shifting allegiances and fierce lobbying on both sides of the issue.
snippet: The 217-205 vote was far closer than expected and displayed the shifting allegiances and fierce lobbying on both sides of the issue.

lead_paragraph: The press secretary, Jay Carney, said the Obama administration was “extremely disappointed” with the Russian government’s granting temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden.

headline.main: White House Reacts to Snowden Asylum

snippet: The press secretary, Jay Carney, said the Obama administration was “extremely disappointed” with the Russian government’s granting temporary asylum to Edward J. Snowden.

lead_paragraph: The refugee status in Russia was the first formal support from another government for Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor wanted for leaking details of surveillance programs.

headline.main: Defiant Russia Grants Snowden Year’s Asylum
headline.sub:
Despite Strong U.S.
Protest, Leaker Gets
Temporary Status
headline.print_headline: Defiant Russia Grants Snowden Year’s Asylum

abstract: "Russia, brushing aside pleas and warnings from Pres Obama and other senior officials, grants Edward J Snowden one year's asylum and allows him to walk free out of Moscow airport despite risk of breach in relations with United States;" refugee status in Russia is first formal support from another government for Snowden, former intelligence contractor wanted for leaking details of surveillance programs.
snippet: The refugee status in Russia was the first formal support from another government for Edward J. Snowden, the former intelligence contractor wanted for leaking details of surveillance programs.

byline.contributor: Andrew Roth and Nikolay Khalip contributed reporting from Moscow, and Mark Landler from Washington.
byline.original: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ANDREW E. KRAMER

lead_paragraph: The dispute over Edward J. Snowden is less a singular sore point between the United States and Russia than a symptom of a relationship that has soured across the board.

headline.main: Obama’s Fall Moscow Trip Is Even More in Doubt
headline.print_headline: Obama’s Fall Moscow Trip Is Even More in Doubt

abstract: Pres Obama is even less likely to visit Moscow in fall after Russia's decision to grant Edward J Snowden temporary asylum; dispute over Snowden is less a singular sore point between the United States and Russia than a symptom of a relationship that has soured across the board.
snippet: The dispute over Edward J. Snowden is less a singular sore point between the United States and Russia than a symptom of a relationship that has soured across the board.

lead_paragraph: The government is stumbling in its efforts to protect its secrets in the Internet age.

headline.main: A Washington Riddle: What Is ‘Top Secret’?
headline.print_headline: A Washington Riddle: What Is ‘Top Secret’?

abstract: News analysis; disclosures of classified information by Pfc Bradley Manning and Edward J Snowden underscore how the government is stumbling in its efforts to protect its secrets in the Internet age.
snippet: The government is stumbling in its efforts to protect its secrets in the Internet age.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: A gathering hosted Friday by Secretary of State John Kerry and Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel could decide the fate of a summit meeting next month.

headline.main: Kerry, Hagel and Russians Will Meet on Issues Imperiling Obama-Putin Visit
headline.print_headline: Kerry, Hagel and Russians Will Meet on Issues Imperiling Obama-Putin Visit

abstract: Sec of State John Kerry and Defense Sec Chuck Hagel plan to meet in Washington with Russian officials Sergey V Lavrov and Sergei K Shoigu for day of talks that could determine fate of September summit meeting between Pres Obama and Pres Vladimir V Putin; meeting has been thrown into question by issues including Russia’s refusal to return Edward J Snowden to United States.
snippet: A gathering hosted Friday by Secretary of State John Kerry and Secretary of Defense Chuck Hagel could decide the fate of a summit meeting next month.

byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear reported from Washington, and Steven Lee Myers from Moscow.
byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and STEVEN LEE MYERS

lead_paragraph: The partnership that Mr. Obama sought to build with Russia is seriously broken.

headline.main: What’s the Point of a Summit?
headline.print_headline: What’s the Point of a Summit?

abstract: Editorial urges Pres Obama to cancel planned summit meeting with Russian Pres Vladimir Putin; notes that on top of all the other legitimate grievances Obama has with Putin's policies, Putin essentially stuck a thumb in Obama's eye by grating asylum to Edward Snowden.
snippet: The partnership that Mr. Obama sought to build with Russia is seriously broken.

lead_paragraph: The sides have been at loggerheads over arms control, missile defense, Syria, trade and human rights, and Obama aides said Moscow was no longer responding to their proposals.

headline.main: Ties Fraying, Obama Drops Putin Meeting
headline.print_headline: Obama Cancels Summit Meeting With Putin, Imperiling New Arms Cuts

abstract: Pres Obama cancels Moscow summit meeting, ending for now his signature effort to transform Russian-American relations and potentially dooming his aspirations for further nuclear arms cuts before leaving office; concludes that sides have grown so far apart again that there is no point in sitting down with Pres Vladimir Putin.
snippet: The sides have been at loggerheads over arms control, missile defense, Syria, trade and human rights, and Obama aides said Moscow was no longer responding to their proposals.

byline.contributor: Peter Baker reported from Nantucket, Mass., and Steven Lee Myers from Moscow. Michael D. Shear contributed reporting from Washington, and Elisabeth Bumiller from Aspen, Colo.
byline.original: By PETER BAKER and STEVEN LEE MYERS

lead_paragraph: Readers discuss President Obama’s cancellation of a meeting and a column by Frank Bruni about the Olympics.

headline.main: Our Sour Relationship With Putin
headline.print_headline: Our Sour Relationship With Putin

snippet: Readers discuss President Obama’s cancellation of a meeting and a column by Frank Bruni about the Olympics.

lead_paragraph: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.

headline.main: President Moves to Ease Worries on Surveillance
headline.print_headline: President Moves To Ease Worries On Surveillance

abstract: "Pres Obama seeks to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs;" shows no inclination to curtail secret surveillance efforts brought to light by Edward J Snowden’s leaks.
snippet: President Obama sought to take control of the surveillance debate, releasing a legal justification for domestic spying and calling for more scrutiny of National Security Agency programs.

byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and MICHAEL D. SHEAR

lead_paragraph: Readers react to the president’s attempt to reassure the public.

headline.main: Obama’s Defense of Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Obama’s Defense of Surveillance

snippet: Readers react to the president’s attempt to reassure the public.

lead_paragraph: The documents show that the United States conducted 231 cyberoperations in 2011, even while the Obama administration protested other countries’ attacks on American computer networks.

headline.main: Budget Documents Detail Extent of U.S. Cyberoperations
headline.print_headline: An American Cyberoperations Offensive

abstract: Documents leaked by former National Security Agency contractor Edward J Snowden reveal that American intelligence agencies are conducting offensive cyberoperations against other nations, even as Obama administration protests attacks on American computer networks by China, Iran and Russia; cyberattacks are still regarded as part of secret arsenal that officials will not discuss.
snippet: The documents show that the United States conducted 231 cyberoperations in 2011, even while the Obama administration protested other countries’ attacks on American computer networks.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: President Dilma Rousseff, angered over revelations of N.S.A. spying on her and her aides, delivered a sharp rebuke to the Obama administration.

headline.main: Brazil’s Leader Postpones State Visit to Washington Over Spying
headline.print_headline: Brazil’s Leader Postpones State Visit to Washington Over Spying

abstract: Brazilian Pres Dilma Rousseff says she is postponing visit to United States, delivering sharp rebuke to Obama administration over revelations that National Security Agency spied on her, her inner circle of top aides and Brazilian oil giant Petrobras; move highlights way that disclosures of United States surveillance by Edward Snowden are aggravating Washington's ties with array of nations.
snippet: President Dilma Rousseff, angered over revelations of N.S.A. spying on her and her aides, delivered a sharp rebuke to the Obama administration.

byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court released a previously classified opinion in which it said the National Security Agency’s call-log program was constitutional and did not violate Americans’ privacy rights.

headline.main: Extended Ruling by Secret Court Backs Collection of Phone Data
headline.print_headline: Extended Ruling by Secret Court Backs Collection of Phone Data

abstract: "Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court releases previously classified opinion, written by federal Judge Claire V Eagan, explaining why National Security Agency program to keep records of private phone calls was constitutional and did not violate Americans'  privacy rights;" legal analysis endorsed by Eagan echoes basic arguments that  Obama administration has made in defending the program since it came to light in June after leaks by former NSA contractor Edward J Snowden.
snippet: The Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court released a previously classified opinion in which it said the National Security Agency’s call-log program was constitutional and did not violate Americans’ privacy rights.

lead_paragraph: The vast scale of eavesdropping abroad by the N.S.A. angers allies and undercuts America’s influence.

headline.main: New Leaks, New Repercussions
headline.print_headline: New Leaks, New Repercussions

abstract: Editorial warns the vast scale of eavesdropping abroad by National Security Agency, latest revelation of which has angered France, appears to be undercutting America's ability to influence global affairs through example and moral leadership; urges Pres Obama to honor his vow to review electronic intelligence gathering and the institutions charged with judicial and political oversight of such activities.
snippet: The vast scale of eavesdropping abroad by the N.S.A. angers allies and undercuts America’s influence.

keywords.value: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
keywords.name: subject

lead_paragraph: Representative Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said the National Security Agency’s surveillance program was designed to protect the countries from the threat of terror.

headline.main: Lawmaker Offers Strong Defense of U.S. Surveillance Efforts in Europe

snippet: Representative Mike Rogers, chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, said the National Security Agency’s surveillance program was designed to protect the countries from the threat of terror.

headline.main: Clemency for Snowden? U.S. Officials Say No

abstract: The White House and two key members of Congress rejected Edward J. Snowden’s plea for clemency for his disclosures of classified surveillance documents.
snippet: The White House and two key members of Congress rejected Edward J. Snowden’s plea for clemency for his disclosures of classified surveillance documents.

lead_paragraph: The Obama administration on Monday made public a trove of documents, including a court ruling that approved a program to track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.

headline.main: Latest Release of Documents on N.S.A. Includes 2004 Ruling on Email Surveillance
headline.print_headline: Latest Release of Documents on N.S.A. Includes 2004 Ruling on Email Surveillance

abstract: Obama administration releases trove of declassified documents related to National Security Agency surveillance, including ruling in which the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court first approved a program to systematically track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.
snippet: The Obama administration on Monday made public a trove of documents, including a court ruling that approved a program to track Americans’ emails during the Bush administration.

keywords.value: Office of the Director of National Intelligence
keywords.name: organizations

byline.original: By CHARLIE SAVAGE and JAMES RISEN

lead_paragraph: Investigators remain in the dark partly because the facility where the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden worked was not equipped with software to monitor employees.

headline.main: Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowden’s Leaks
headline.print_headline: Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowden’s Leaks

abstract: "American intelligence and law enforcement investigators conclude that they may never know full extent of classified documents extracted by former National Security Agency contractor Edward J Snowden;" thwarted investigation, and Snowden's continued ability to hack into system and cover his tracks, illustrate how far computer security has lagged at America's intelligence agencies.
snippet: Investigators remain in the dark partly because the facility where the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden worked was not equipped with software to monitor employees.

byline.original: By MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

lead_paragraph: The president’s choices in the next few weeks may define America’s approach to national security long after his term is over.

headline.main: Obama Weighing Security and Privacy in Deciding on Spy Program Limits
headline.print_headline: Obama Weighing Security and Privacy in Deciding on Spy Program Limits

abstract: Choices Pres Obama makes over spy program limits may define America’s approach to national security long after his term is over; in last five years he has grown dependent on National Security Agency for countering terrorist threats; it is major balancing act between security system and principles of privacy.
snippet: The president’s choices in the next few weeks may define America’s approach to national security long after his term is over.

lead_paragraph: At the heart of the report by a White House advisory group about America’s surveillance state is a challenge to President Obama’s conception of his presidency.

headline.main: A Legacy in the Balance on Surveillance Policies
headline.print_headline: A Legacy in the Balance On Surveillance Policies

abstract: News analysis; White House advisory group report about America’s surveillance state presents challenge to Pres Obama’s conception of his presidency; report urges him to rachet back expansive intelligence apparatus, and he must decide whether such recalibration would unreasonably increase risk of terrorists slipping through surveillance net.
snippet: At the heart of the report by a White House advisory group about America’s surveillance state is a challenge to President Obama’s conception of his presidency.

lead_paragraph: In his news conference, the president, yet again, offers little more than bland reassurances on the government’s runaway surveillance policy.

headline.main: Mr. Obama’s Disappointing Response
headline.print_headline: Mr. Obama’s Disappointing Response

abstract: Editorial holds Pres Obama repeated only bland reassurances at news conference on findings of his handpicked panel on data collection policies; contends he shows no signs of halting the program or rewriting passage of the Patriot act that justifies it.
snippet: In his news conference, the president, yet again, offers little more than bland reassurances on the government’s runaway surveillance policy.

lead_paragraph: A judge and a presidential panel slam the N.S.A.’s snooping as a mass invasion of privacy.

headline.main: Bad Times for Big Brother
headline.print_headline: Bad Times for Big Brother

abstract: Editorial observes Obama administration report on NSA's practices has brought all three branches of the federal government to agreement that the National Security Agency has misused, if not plainly abused, its surveillance powers; calls on Congress and the courts to set firm limits on all surveillance programs and to ensure that the administration complies.
snippet: A judge and a presidential panel slam the N.S.A.’s snooping as a mass invasion of privacy.

lead_paragraph: President Obama, responding on Friday to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, said he would require intelligence agencies to get court permission before tapping into a vast trove of phone data.

headline.main: Keeping Wide Net, Obama Sets Limits on Phone Spying
headline.print_headline: KEEPING WIDE NET, OBAMA SETS LIMITS ON PHONE SPYING

snippet: President Obama, responding on Friday to months of debate set off by the disclosures of Edward J. Snowden, said he would require intelligence agencies to get court permission before tapping into a vast trove of phone data.

byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE

lead_paragraph: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.

headline.main: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying
headline.print_headline: Obama Outlines Calibrated Curbs on Phone Spying

abstract: "Pres Obama, responding to clamor over the National Security Agency's spying practices, announces significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records;" Obama nonetheless defends need for the broad surveillance net assembled by agency, disappointing privacy advocates.
snippet: In a speech that seemed more calculated to reassure audiences at home and abroad than to force radical change, President Obama announced significant changes to the way the government collects and uses telephone records.

byline.contributor: Peter Baker and David E. Sanger contributed reporting.
byline.original: By MARK LANDLER and CHARLIE SAVAGE

lead_paragraph: Restoring trust in government agencies requires more than a few good restrictions on collecting personal data.

headline.main: The President on Mass Surveillance
headline.print_headline: The President on Mass Surveillance

abstract: Editorial cites Pres Obama's speech announcing important new restrictions on the collection of phone records and other information about ordinary Americans; contends reforms are frustratingly short on specifics and vague on implementation; criticizes Obama for failing to mention Edward Snowden, without whose efforts reform would not be on table.
snippet: Restoring trust in government agencies requires more than a few good restrictions on collecting personal data.

headline.main: America to Obama: We're Not Listening

abstract: The president has vowed to create a rational policy on spying so many times that no one seems to be paying attention anymore.
snippet: The president has vowed to create a rational policy on spying so many times that no one seems to be paying attention anymore.

lead_paragraph: The United States did not specify the guilty pleas it would expect from Edward J. Snowden before opening talks.

headline.main: U.S. Willing to Hold Talks if Snowden Pleads Guilty
headline.print_headline: U.S. Willing to Hold Talks if Snowden Pleads Guilty

abstract: Atty Gen Eric H Holder Jr says United States is willing to discuss how the criminal case against Edward J Snowden will be handled, but only if Snowden pleads guilty first.
snippet: The United States did not specify the guilty pleas it would expect from Edward J. Snowden before opening talks.

lead_paragraph: The lawmaker hinted that the extension of temporary refugee status for the former National Security Agency contractor might be indefinite.

headline.main: Russia Plans to Extend Snowden Asylum, Lawmaker Says
headline.print_headline: Russia: Lawmaker Hints at New Offer for Snowden

abstract: Russian lawmaker Aleksei K Pushkov says his country plans to extend its offer of asylum to Edward J Snowden beyond August 2014.
snippet: The lawmaker hinted that the extension of temporary refugee status for the former National Security Agency contractor might be indefinite.

byline.original: By MICHAEL J. de la MERCED

lead_paragraph: Representative Bill Owens, a New York Democrat, responds to a front-page article.

headline.main: To Stop Another Snowden
headline.print_headline: To Stop Another Snowden

abstract: Letter from New York Rep Bill Owens responds to Jan 15 article on Pres Obama's new guidelines for curtailing government surveillance.
snippet: Representative Bill Owens, a New York Democrat, responds to a front-page article.

headline.main: Did Big Internet Companies Handicap Start-Ups in FISA Rule Changes?

abstract: A small but significant caveat, in a new agreement brokered between the Obama administration and tech companies could cast a long shadow over America’s technology start-ups.
snippet: A small but significant caveat, in a new agreement brokered between the Obama administration and tech companies could cast a long shadow over America’s technology start-ups.

lead_paragraph: The Obama administration will allow Internet companies to talk more specifically about when they are forced to turn over customer data to the government, the Justice Department said.

headline.main: U.S. Relaxes Some Data Disclosure Rules
headline.print_headline: U.S. Relaxes Some Data Disclosure Rules

abstract: Obama administration unveils new declassification rules that will allow Internet companies to give customers a better idea of how often the government demands their information, though they may not disclose what is being collected or how much; new rules have prompted Google, Microsoft, Yahoo and Facebook to drop respective lawsuits before the nation's secret surveillance court.
snippet: The Obama administration will allow Internet companies to talk more specifically about when they are forced to turn over customer data to the government, the Justice Department said.

byline.original: By MATT APUZZO and NICOLE PERLROTH

lead_paragraph: The newspaper, Süddeutsche Zeitung, reported that American intelligence services began monitoring Chancellor Gerhard Schröder after he opposed the Bush administration’s plan to go to war in Iraq.

headline.main: German Paper Says U.S. Kept Tabs on Leader
headline.print_headline: German Paper Says U.S. Kept Tabs on Leader

abstract: German newspaper Suddeutsche Zeitung reports that American intelligence services began monitoring Chancellor Gerhard Schroder in 2002 and perhaps earlier; Schroder openly opposed Bush administration’s plan to go to war in Iraq.
snippet: The newspaper, Süddeutsche Zeitung, reported that American intelligence services began monitoring Chancellor Gerhard Schröder after he opposed the Bush administration’s plan to go to war in Iraq.
